My name is Rajan, and growing up in a small, rural town, the only real “classrooms” I ever knew were the dusty open-air ones beneath a baobab tree. I never made it past seventh grade, but life had a way of pushing me forward anyway. At sixteen, I volunteered with the local militia, drawn in by the promise of belonging and a sense of purpose I couldn’t find elsewhere. That’s how I found myself—by chance more than choice—enlisting as a private in the national army.

Life in the armed forces was unlike anything I’d known. The discipline sharpened me, the camaraderie gave me family, but the daily grind—long marches, harsh rations, and the ever-present weight of responsibility—was tough. I wasn’t the brightest recruit, but what I lacked in intellect, I made up for with grit and a keen eye for detail in patrol rounds. Over the years, through hard work and perseverance, I earned my way up as an officer, overseeing units in remote border outposts where most people would have quit long ago.

Now, I oversee patrols that keep the region safe from bandits and instability. The isolation and danger are sometimes overwhelming; nights are spent staring at stars wondering if my wife back home (who I haven’t seen in two years due to postings) is alright. I work long hours, but the sense of duty keeps me going

My name is Rajiv, and growing up in a small village outside Delhi, formal schooling was never really a priority for my father, the head constable of our local police station. My education stopped at seventh grade; after that, helping on the family farm took most of my time. Still, I taught myself Hindi and a smattering of mathematics, using battered textbooks and radio lessons.  
  
By twenty-one, I joined the Indian Army as an officer trainee, a path suggested by my uncle who also served. The rigorous physical training, strict discipline, and camaraderie among fellow recruits shaped me into someone disciplined and resilient. Daily life on the base was structured—watches to tend, routines to follow, but there was always a sense of purpose in uniform.  

Despite my high rank now (corporal), I often feel a gap between my ambition and the opportunities available. Promotions come slowly for those with limited formal education, and many of my peers with degrees are ahead of me. I dream of leading a platoon in a critical mission, but self-doubt creeps in when I see others shine with less effort and more learning.  

At home, my mother prays for my success, and my younger sister looks up to me as a role model. I try to help her with her studies, even though I can’t always explain algebra beyond “it’s like solving puzzles.”

My name is Raj, and most people in my neighborhood simply call me “Raj the Boss”—a nickname I earned long before I ever wore a suit. Born in a small town where formal schooling was rare for many, I never made it beyond primary school. Still, I taught myself numbers and words by listening to radio lessons and working odd jobs to help my family. My parents always said education was a ladder, so I carried that belief, even if the rungs looked out of reach early on.

At twenty-two, I landed a management job in a bustling city kiosk, running sales on the street corners. It started as just after hours, counting cash and telling my small crew what to do. Gradually, the owner saw my knack for organizing, negotiating, and keeping everyone motivated. He gave me my first real chance at leadership. Over the next decade, I climbed the commercial food and beverage chain—first as a supervisor, then as a department head, and eventually as a store manager. My pay isn’t high, but I appreciate the respect and the freedom that come with managing my own team.

Every morning begins before dawn: a cup of chai, a quick check of the registers, and a brief family call—mostly to update my sister, who still can’t read or write. I feel the weight of responsibility, but also pride in providing for my extended family, even with a modest income. My
